div.div: How to prepare DITA content for localization
Chapter . Writing with localization in mind
Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.
Importing a DITA project into memoQ

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.

section.p: A text that is easy to understand is usually also easier to translate. To make your writing clearer, use these tips:

ul.li: Avoid overly long sentences and paragraphs.
Repeat important words to avoid misunderstanding.
Don't describe more than one action in a sentence unless writing about strictly related actions.
Use words such as "and," "then," "but," "a," "the," "this," and "that" to make your message clear.
Make sure that each term has only one meaning.

section.p: You can make your text easier to understand by using certain grammatical forms. To make your writing clearer, follow these rules:

ul.li: Express actions with verbs, not nouns.
Split clusters of nouns into smaller logical units.

section.p: Search your text for unintended linebreaks and punctuation marks (such as periods in place of commas). Translation tools may misinterpret such characters and split sentences into separate units. This can lead to translation errors and inconsistencies.
section.div: Important: When localizing a DITA project, always send the translators your source files rather than the output, for example PDF or HTML files.

li.a: Resolving conrefs, keyrefs, and conkeyrefs (on page )
